items.title: Query your parents with CSS
items.content:
#â€‹582 â€” March 1, 2023 | Read on the web

Getting Started with Style Queries â€” The ability to query a parentâ€™s inline size, and container query unit values (using the @container rule) recently reached stable support in all modern browser engines (though the broader container style queries spec still has some way to go). Hereâ€™s a look at how to get started withÂ theÂ feature.

Una Kravets (Chrome Developers)

Let's Build a Chrome Extension That 'Steals Everything' â€” Indulging in what they call â€œDIY whole hog data exfiltrationâ€, Matt, the author of Building Browser Extensions demonstrates that in spite of Manifest v3, a whole lot of bad stuff is still possible when it comes to building browser extensions. Be aware of it and donâ€™t actually do it, ofÂ course.

Matt Frisbie

Get a Complete Picture of Your Siteâ€™s Performance â€” Track Core Web Vitals and learn how users experience the speed of your site. Use Lighthouse audits to fix issues. Measure the impact of slowdowns on business metrics and user engagement. Integrate with your CI/CD process to stayÂ fast.

SpeedCurve sponsor

On Container Queries, Responsive Images, and JPEG-XL â€” Now that one major element of CSS Container Queries has shipped in nearly all modern browsers, Jason notes that itâ€™s time to revisit responsive images and ask how they fit in a container query world. Are we on the rightÂ path?

Jason Grigsby

A Guide to Accessible Form Validation â€” What you need to take into consideration so that nobody gets stuck on an inaccessible invalidÂ field.

Sandrina Pereira

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Chrome has long been considered a resource hog on modern Macs, but the latest release of Chrome improves things a lot, says the Chrome team.

  • Last week we featured news of Web Push support in iOS, but Roderick Gadellaa notes that the current implementation "kind of defeats a key point of the web".

Zoran Jambor

Intro to HTML-First Frontend Frameworks â€” The post defines HTML-first front-end frameworks as ones that prioritize sending complete functional HTML versus a JavaScript bundle, and looks at some of the different approaches taken by different tools like Marko, Astro, Eleventy, andÂ Enhance.

SitePen Engineering

PolyScale.ai sponsor

Yuan Chuan

ScrollTrigger: Let Your Page React to Scroll Changes â€” Triggers classes based on the current scroll position. So, for example, when an element enters the viewport you can fade itÂ in.

Erik Terwan

No SVG, No Image, CSS-Only Fluid Slider with input[type=range] â€” This is an impressive CSS demo, showcasing an animated, color-changing slider. Browser support for certain features used (such as color-mix) isÂ limited.

Kobalte: A UI Toolkit for Building Accessible Web Apps and Design Systems with SolidJS â€” The components are unstyled and follow WAI-ARIA authoring practices. You also have granular access to each component part, allowing you to add event listeners, props, etc.
